s.gd: ’S e maduinn samhraidh a bh’ ann.
s.en: It was a summer morning.

s.gd: Laigh samhchar trom air Baile nam Muileann, oir cha robh e fhathast ach tràth.
s.en: A heavt silence settled on Milltown, because it was still only early.

s.gd: Shuas air druim a’ bhaile bha ceò ag èaladh gu mall chun na h-àirde a deas bho shimilearan nan tighean ùra.
s.en: Up the back of the town, smoke was creeping slowly in a southerly direction from the chimneys of the new houses.

s.gd: Bha osag fhann de ghaoith an iar ann.
s.en: There was a faint gust of westerly wind.

s.gd: Thàinig i thairis a’ mhonaidh is na cnuic, milis le àileadh an fhraoich agus falaisgearan fad as.
s.en: It came across the moor and the hills, sweet with the scent of heather and distant heath fires.

s.gd: Shéid i steach air uinneig uachdraich seòmar Mhurchaidh Anna, agus ghlac a chuinnleanan i far an robh e fhathast ’na laighe air a leabaidh shuas-straighre ’san tigh ùr a thog e an uiridh.
s.en: It blew inside the upper window of Anna’ Murdo’s room, and his nostrils caught it where he was still lying on his bed upstairs in the new house which he had built last year.

s.gd: Thug anail na h-osaig gu a chuimhne làithean eile agus falaisgearan eile a chaidh as bho chionn fhada.
s.en: The breath of the gust brought to his memory other days and other heath fires which had had been long forgotten.

s.gd: Làithean sona na h-àirigh air Stacaiseal, Ceann Allabhat, Na Cleiteachan . . . .
s.en: The happy days of the summer pastures on Stacashal, Ceann Allavat, the Cleiteachan ....

s.gd: Ach cha robh ann ach faoineas a bhith tighinn air nithean a chaidh thairis.
s.en: But there was only the futility of coming on things that were over.

s.gd: Bha là ùr air teachd.
s.en: A new day had come.

s.gd: Dh’ fheumadh e bhith gluasad a mach bho’n chuibhrig ged a bha e sgìth an déidh an là-an-dé a chur seachad a’ rùsgadh mòine Iain Bhig.
s.en: H would have to move out from the quilt even though he was tired after the day before which he spent cutting Little John’s peat.

s.gd: Agus air tilleadh dhà, chuir e am blàr shnèap.
s.en: And on returning [to him], he sewed the turnip field.

s.gd: Greis eile a’ toirt làmh-chuidich do Iain a mhac, a’ deilbh clò, agus aig Sealbh a bha fhios cuin a fhuair e g’ a leabaidh.
s.en: Another while giving a helping hand to his son John, designing cloth, and Heaven knows when he got to his bed.

s.gd: Co dhiùbh, bha ’n gloc ’na stad—bho’n oidhche ud, mìos air ais, nuair a thuit e as a làmhan.
s.en: In any case, the clock was stopped–since that night, a month back, when it fell from his hands.

s.gd: Gloc na h-éiginn dhà-san, oir cha do stad teanga Anna dheth a riamh bho sguir bìogail borb an uaireadair-cluig anns na maidnean.
s.en: The emergency clck for him, because Anne’s tongue never stopped [of it] since the sharp chirping of the bell-clock in the mornings.

s.gd: Is leis a h-uile sgiorradh a bha ’na dhéidh m’ an ám so de’n bhliadhna cha robh e a’ faighinn de dh’ anail a leigeadh leis Domhnull Aonghais Choinnich a ruighinn leis an inneal.
s.en: And with all the stumbling that was after it around this time of the year, he was not getting a breath to let Donald Angus Kenneth arrive with the machine.

s.gd: Carson an ainm gliocais a bha daoine air an riaghladh le glocaichean?
s.en: Why in the name of wisdom were men governed by clocks?

s.gd: Ged tha, bha thìd a bhith ’g éirigh.
s.en: However, it was time to be getting up.

s.gd: Shìn e a chasan, sparr e a ghàirdeanan os cionn a chinn, mhèarain e, dh’ altaich e a shùilean, thilg e an t-aodach-leapa a thaobh is chuir e car dheth fhéin chun an làir.
s.en: He stretched his legs, he thrust his arms above his head, he yawned, he relaxed his eyes, he threw the bedclothes aside and he shifted himself to the floor.

s.gd: Tharruing e uime a stocainnean is a bhriogais, is rinn e air an uinneig.
s.en: He pulled on his socks and his trousers, and he made for the window.

s.gd: Sheall e air coltas an adhair is shaoil leis gum faca e iomadh coltas ni bu mhiosa.
s.en: He looked at the appearance of the sky and it semed to him that he had seen many a worse appearance.

s.gd: Co dhiùbh, bha a’ ghrian ris is an t-adhar gorm.
s.en: In any case, the sun was on him and the sky blue.

s.gd: Thug e dà cheum air ais gu oisean na leapa, agus—dé an sporghail a bh’ oirre-se shios-staighre?
s.en: He took two steps back to the corner of the bed, and–what was the rummaging that was on her downstairs?

s.gd: Bha i a’ stàirnich an sud bho’n dubh mhoch-eirigh a rinn i an diugh gun fhios fo’n ghréin carson.
s.en: She was clattering there since the dark early-rising that she did today without knowing under the sun why.

s.gd: Thog e a sheacaid bho phost na leapa, shad e uime i, agus stad e.
s.en: He lifted his njacket from the bed post, he threw it on, and he stopped.

s.gd: Dé air an talamh an iorghail a bha dol air adhart anns na badaibh a bha shios?
s.en: What on Earth was the tumult that was going on in the places that were down there?

s.gd: Sin chuala e sgriachail circe agus bualadh sgiathan.
s.en: Then he heard a hen screeching and flapping of wings.

s.gd: ’S ann a’ mort circe a bhiodh i.
s.en: She would be killing a hen.

s.gd: Gu rachadh leatha is gun tarruingeadh i an sgornan as a h-uile cearc a bha eadar dà cheann a’ bhaile.
s.en: ... and that she would pull the neck in every hen that was between the two ends of the town.

s.gd: Is esan a bha seachd sgìth dhiubh.
s.en: And him who was so tired of them.

s.gd: Eil fhios an robh gin de na donais anns a’ bhlàr shnèap a chuir e an raoir?
s.en: Is it known whether any of the devils were in the turnip field which he sowed last night?

s.gd: Thill e chun na h-uinneig, thog e ni b’ àirde i, chuir e a cheann a mach is thug e sùil sìos air a’ bhlàr shnèap mu choinneamh an tighe.
s.en: He returned to the window, he lifted it higher, he put his head out and he looked down on the turnip field in front of the house.

s.gd: Chunnaic e na sgriosadairean an sàs agus cha do chùm e air na b’ fhaide.
s.en: He saw the destroyers involved and he did not keep on himself longer.

s.gd: “Seall air na diobhail,” ars’ esan.
s.en: “Look at the devils,” he said.

s.gd: “Ged tha, cuiridh mise smùid as na h-itean aca.
s.en: “Even so, I will put smoke in their feathers.

s.gd: An dà leum bha e shìos an staighre.
s.en: In two leaps he was down the stairs.

s.gd: “Daimon! Daimon!” dh’ éigh e.
s.en: “Daimon! Daimon!” he yelled.

s.gd: “Thoir leat iad.”
s.en: “Take them.”

s.gd: Sud Murchadh an ceann a stocainnean, is an cù molach, Daimon, a mach roimhe air dorus nan uaislibh.
s.en: There was Murdo after his socks, and the shaggy dog, Daimon, outside in front of the door of the gentry.

s.gd: “Leat iad, thoir leat iad,” arsa Murchadh.
s.en: “Get them, get them,” said Murdo.

s.gd: Leum an cù is e ri sgaltaich a measg nan cearc.
s.en: The dog jumped and him screaming among the hens.
